text.0: maghavan indra turns his chariot downward the strengthdisplaying car which he hath mounted.
text.1: even as a herdsman driveth forth his cattle he goeth first uninjured fain for treasure.
text.2: haste to us lord of bays be not ungracious visit us lover of goldhued oblation.
text.3: there is naught else better than thou art indra een to the wifeless hast thou given spouses.
text.4: when out of strength arose the strength that conquers indra displayed all powers that he possesses.
text.5: forth from the cave he drove the milky mothers and with the light laid bare investing darkness.
text.6: anus have wrought a chariot for thy courser and tvaṣṭar muchinvoked thy bolt that glitters.
text.7: the brahmans with their songs exalting indra increased his strength that he might slaughter ahi.
text.8: when heroes sang their laud to thee the hero indra and stones and aditi accordant.
text.9: without or steed or chariot were the fellies which sped by indra rolled upon the dasytis.
text.10: i will declare thine exploits wrought aforetime and maghavan thy deeds of late achievement.
text.11: when lord of might thou sunderedst earth and heaven winning for man the moistlygleaming waters.
text.12: this is thy deed een this wonderful singer that slaying ahi here thy strength thou showedst.
text.13: didst check and stay een gusnas wiles and magic and drawing nigh didst chase away the dasytis.
text.14: thou indra on the farther bank foryadu and turvaga didst stay the gushing waters.
text.15: ye both assailed the fierce thou barest kutsa when gods and uśanā came to you together.
text.16: let the steeds bring you both indra and kutsa borne on the chariot within hearingdistance.
text.17: ye blew him from the waters from his dwelling and chased the darkness from the nobles spirit.
text.18: even this sage hath come looking for succour even to vātas docile harnessed horses.
text.19: here are the maruts all thy dear companions prayers have increased thy power and might o indra.
text.20: when night was near its close he carried forward een the suns chariot backward in its running.
text.21: etaga brought his wheel and firmly stays it setting it eastward he shall give us courage.
text.22: this indra o ye men hath come to see you seeking a friend who hath expressed the soma.
text.23: the creaking stone is laid upon the altar and the adhvaryus come to turn it quickly.
text.24: let mortals who were happy still be happy let them not come to sorrow o immortal.
text.25: love thou the pious and to these thy peoplewith whom may we be numberedgive thou vigour.
